[The Sinking of the German Light Cruiser "Nurmberg". This picture, published in a German illustrated papers purports[?] It shows the sinking of the German light cruiser "Nurmberg" by English armored cruisers, after the battle of the Falkland Islands. The picture is supposed to represent the incident at the moment when the "Nurmberg" summoned by the English flagship upheld[?] the "German warships never surrender."]

Caption: The Work of A German Torpedo. English steamer Maseton sinking south of Ireland, shot at night out of convoy. In his installment Mr. Thomas will tell of raids o this kind on Allied merchant vevssels. (handwritten:) Cut made for April 1928.
Caption: Cut made for May 1928.

Caption: A SHIPPING CASUALTY OF THE WORLD WAR An authentic photograph taken from a British blimp of a merchant ship sinking rapidly after being torpedoed by a German submarine on December 19, 1917. A British destroyer hrueld a depth charge after the submerged submarine, a hit being revealed by the appearance of oil on the surface thirteen minutes after the freighter had been torpedoed.

[Berlin, May 5, 1929. Dear Mr. Thomas :- Spending a nice evening together at my home, we have resolved to send you this sign of our remembrance. I trust you will let me know whenever you come across. Very sincerely yours, Robert Motaht[?], Top U-boat Capt. P.S. in the meantime we'll drink a little schnaps to your health Josephine Lehman]

Verso: Berlin, May 5, 1929. Dear Mr. Thomas :- Spending a nice evening together at my home, we have resolved to send you this sign of our remembrance.
